title: What will the monthly Period-over-Period change in the consumer price index (CPI) be for Estonia in August 2017?
preds: Read the prompt wrong. Previous forecast was index, not month on month change.
Difficult forecast. I did some data manipulation to look at this in a couple different ways. Consumer confidence remains high in the region which is really messing with me. Average august is -.14.
Following the forecaster who lives in Estonia.

Aaarrggh!! Struggling with my typing here today. Sorry, reversed the numbers. Sigh. Oops sorry, mistyped this! "However Britain did not have the highest rate of inflation in Europe during the month, with Lithuania registering a 4.1% rise in prices and Estonia recording a rate of 3.9%." https://www.rte.ie/news/business/2017/0817/898023-euro-zone-inflation/ Upward pressure on food prices last month, doesn't seem to be any government action to slow: http://news.err.ee/614267/july-meat-prices-up-milk-prices-surge-over-60-percent-on-year
Increased producer prices likely to push up consumer prices as well: http://news.err.ee/613973/july-industrial-producer-price-index-up-4-1-percent-on-year AND: "Consumer prices were also impacted by the continued increase in the price of services, an increase in the price of energy affected by higher electricity prices on the stock market and an increase in some food prices, he said." http://news.err.ee/611575/ministry-of-finance-taxes-increased-inflation-by-one-percent-in-july Don't see any trends so far that suggest any action to lower the creeping rise here; only those that suggest more increase.  So looking at the news and the data, I think .25 could be possible, but more than .35 also is likely.
Based on trends and geopolitical uncertainty.

Estimating Aug CPI at 0.21. Found that for most components of the CPI the August year over year trend may provide the best base estimate.  The most recent set of Estonian CPI weights (on the Internet) seemed to be the 2008 weights (maybe should have run correlations instead). Some components can act as wildcards: the alcohol tax in June, transport prices that seem to be dependent on the oil price, communications has a few outliers in the series, etc.   Finally, multiplied the weights by a August component estimate, based on the August trend, and summed. Example: Clothing & Footware:
...................June.......July........Aug
2010...........-0.25.....-2.68......0.26
2011.............0.69....-2.85......2.75
2012............-0.24....-4.77......3.90
2013............-0.28....-3.48......2.39
2014............-0.33....-4.72......3.96
2015............-1.41....-5.44......4.77
2016............-1.57...-3.50.......4.29
2017............-3.62...-3.43.......???? Imperfect forecast: ..............Aug (est)......CPI weight
Food.......-1.05................0.217
Housing..0.50.................0.136
Transp....0.00.................0.152
Recreate.0.00.................0.087
Al&T&N...0.50................0.072
Cloths.....4.80.................0.067
Furn........0.50.................0.056
Health...-0.10.................0.038
Comm...-0.20.................0.050
Restrnt...0.00.................0.043
Misc........0.70.................

Just basing this on nothing more than looking at the last 12 months of data. Inflation has never dropped below -.38, it's been in the second band once in the last year, twice in the third, five times in the fourth, and four times in the fifth. Honestly I should probably have some deeper logic or trend analysis but, well, screw it.

Last month's change was 0.64. I looked at what has happened in the past ten years to Estonia's period-over-period CPI change when the previous month's change was over 0.30. Most of the time, CPI change remains over 0.30. The June 2017 OECD forecast predicts an increase in Estonia's inflation rate.

The increase of 0.64 in July was mainly down to a slight increase in energy prices in that month. Oil prices have stabilized again in August while natural gas prices have increased somewhat. With some possible offsetting in other prices, the CPI should remain fairly close to its level in July, with a slight bias to the upside.
Estonia is not in the news right now. Not much going on (I presume) which means no major changes.

I'm following @Dsarin because of his record forecasting here. His ratio of Brier to median is 0.89 and he's on three leaderboards: https://www.gjopen.com/challenges/15-cfa-society-l-a-finance-economics-2017/scores; https://www.gjopen.com/challenges/11-in-the-news/scores; and https://www.gjopen.com/challenges/9-arab-strategy-forum-state-of-the-world-2017/scores. Holy cow, he's good!
Adjusting up, not so convinced about negative number after some data crunching, looks like the effect of (July) tax hikes can flow into next month.
Interest in the investment in and construction of a biomethanol plant could increase consumer optimism  along with the potential for falling unemployment could show an up rick in the CPI.

Question about Estonia, nice, thank you GJO. August is usually cheap due to reduced food prices. With high base from July's alcohol tax hike, expecting mo/mo CPI below 0. http://www.stat.ee/news-release-2017-085

I'm assuming 0.6 = 0.06. 
July 2017 was 0.7%
annualized CPI is 3.6%
I'm predicting change between previous month and yearly average with stronger emphasis von previous months. Based on: „Nothing seems to forecast inflation very well, except inflation’s own history….“ 1 1 Stephen G. Cecchetti , E. Groshen (2000) - Understanding Inflation: Implications for Monetary Policy, NBER Working Paper 7482, 2000, S. 13 f.
http://www.nber.org/papers/w7482.pdf Stephen G. Cecchetti (1995) -  Inflation Indicators and Inflation Policy
http://www.journals.uchicago.edu/doi/abs/10.1086/654274

I'm assuming by 0.6, the question means 0.06.
I'm using 12 month moving average as the mean estimate (=0.3)
I calculated the out-of-sample standard deviation (=0.44) and the probability is based on normal distribution.

The ranges being offered are not contiguous and are misleading.  I am making an assumption that the ".6" option that is being shown should be ".06" in order to create contiguous options.  The current CPI rate change for July in Estonia at the time I make this prediction was 0.7%.  The annualized CPI rate is 3.6%.  Considering that the annualized rate is likely to be a more consistent indicator, I am predicting between the previous month and the average for the past 12 months
Monthly fluctuations have been within these ranges and barring external forces should remain that way.
